intro: Ervatamia pubescens var. glaberrima, commonly known as the glabrous ervatamia, is a flowering plant species native to specific regions of southern Africa. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs, though the variety glaberrima is distinguished by its smoother, hairless foliage. The plant produces clusters of small, yellowish-green flowers that bloom in spring, attracting various pollinators. It thrives in well-drained soils and prefers full sun to partial shade, making it suitable for rock gardens or dry landscapes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological role, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and native plant collections.
